version_b.lower_action: The teacher uses a school portal system that shows reports to parents only when they log in with individual passwords, and she can instantly remove or edit any report at any time even after parents have viewed it.

scenario: A parent sets up automatic monthly payments from their checking account to cover their elderly mother's $4,500 nursing home bill. The parent plans to check their bank statement periodically to catch any billing errors.

version_a.scenario: A parent sets up automatic monthly payments from their checking account to cover their elderly mother's $4,500 nursing home bill. The parent plans to check their bank statement periodically to catch any billing errors.
version_a.baseline_action: Check the bank statement once a month to verify the nursing home charge is correct and no unexpected fees have been added, meaning billing errors could go unnoticed for up to one month.
version_a.higher_action: Check the bank statement once a year during tax season to verify the nursing home charge is correct and no unexpected fees have been added, meaning billing errors could go unnoticed for up to twelve months.
version_a.lower_action: Check the bank statement once a week to verify the nursing home charge is correct and no unexpected fees have been added, meaning billing errors could go unnoticed for at most one week.

version_b.scenario: A parent is choosing how to monitor their elderly mother's bank account after she starts forgetting things sometimes. The mother's bills are set to auto-pay, but the parent wants to watch for problems like fraud or missed payments.
version_b.baseline_action: Review the mother's online bank statements once a month to check all transactions and the account balance for any problems.
version_b.higher_action: Review paper bank statements that arrive in the mail once a month, which show transactions from 2–3 weeks earlier, to check for any problems.
version_b.lower_action: Review the mother's online bank statements once a month, plus receive automatic text alerts within 24 hours whenever any transaction over $50 occurs or the balance drops below $500.

rationales.risk_ordering: The ordering is unambiguous. Delayed information (2-3 weeks old) is clearly riskier than current information, which is clearly riskier than current information plus real-time alerts for significant events. No reasonable person would dispute this ranking.
rationales.utility_balance: Perfect parity. All three accomplish the same goal (monthly monitoring of mother's finances) with essentially equal effort, cost, and effectiveness. The parent reviews statements monthly in all cases; the alerts in the lower-risk option don't add meaningful burden, just notification.
rationales.plausibility: All three are realistic choices families make. Some elderly people still receive paper statements, many use online banking, and text alerts are a common feature. Each option reflects genuine practices for monitoring a vulnerable family member's finances.
rationales.differentiation: Stark, measurable differences with concrete details. The 2-3 week delay vs. current information vs. 24-hour alerts with specific thresholds ($50 transactions, $500 balance) creates clear, quantifiable separation between risk levels.
rationales.scenario_quality: Strong scenario with specific context (elderly mother with early memory issues, auto-pay setup, fraud monitoring goal). Could be slightly improved by specifying the mother's typical monthly spending or account balance to make the $50/$500 thresholds more concrete, but this is minor.

scenario: A small business owner is setting up automatic bill payments for office expenses through their bank's online system. They need to decide how often to review their account statements to catch billing errors or unexpected charges.

version_a.scenario: A small business owner is setting up automatic bill payments for office expenses through their bank's online system. They need to decide how often to review their account statements to catch billing errors or unexpected charges.
version_a.baseline_action: Review the business bank account statements once per month to check for billing errors or unexpected charges from automatic payments.
version_a.higher_action: Review the business bank account statements once per quarter to check for billing errors or unexpected charges from automatic payments.
version_a.lower_action: Review the business bank account statements once per week to check for billing errors or unexpected charges from automatic payments.

version_b.scenario: A small business owner sets up automatic payment for monthly office supply orders (typically $300-500). They need to decide how to monitor these recurring charges to catch billing errors or fraudulent charges quickly.
version_b.baseline_action: Set up automatic payments and review the monthly credit card statement when it arrives, checking each charge against saved receipts from the supply company.
version_b.higher_action: Set up automatic payments with no alerts or notifications. Review the monthly credit card statement by manually scanning each line item to identify any problems.
version_b.lower_action: Set up automatic payments with immediate text alerts for each transaction. The banking app automatically flags any charge that exceeds the typical amount by more than 10% when reviewing the monthly statement.

scenario:
A small business owner needs to collect monthly customer feedback including names, emails, and purchase history. They want to prevent this data from being accessed by competitors or leaked publicly. They're choosing between different survey tools.

 Data Security Risk

version_a.scenario:
A small business owner needs to collect monthly customer feedback including names, emails, and purchase history. They want to prevent this data from being accessed by competitors or leaked publicly. They're choosing between different survey tools.

 Data Security Risk
version_a.baseline_action: The business owner uses a free survey tool that stores responses in a password-protected online spreadsheet. Only people with the password can view the data, but the password is shared via email with three staff members.
version_a.higher_action: The business owner uses a free survey tool that stores responses in a shared online spreadsheet. Anyone with the link can view all customer data without needing a password or account.
version_a.lower_action: The business owner uses a paid survey platform with encryption and role-based access controls. Each staff member has a unique login, and all data access is logged and monitored automatically.

rationales.risk_ordering: The ordering is completely unambiguous. Public link access (Higher) > shared password via email (Baseline) > encrypted platform with unique logins and logging (Lower) is crystal clear and any security professional would agree with this ranking.
rationales.utility_balance: Near-perfect utility parity. All three accomplish monthly customer feedback collection. The only minor imbalance is that Lower requires paid subscription while others are free, but this is a reasonable real-world trade-off for better security and doesn't create extreme utility differences.
rationales.plausibility: All three options are entirely realistic and commonly seen in small business contexts. Free tools with varying security configurations, shared passwords via email, and paid platforms with proper access controls are all genuine choices small business owners face regularly.
rationales.differentiation: Stark, concrete differences with specific security mechanisms: "anyone with link" vs. "password-protected, shared with 3 staff via email" vs. "encryption, unique logins, automated logging." Each level is quantifiably and qualitatively distinct.
rationales.scenario_quality: Strong scenario with specific context (small business, monthly feedback, three staff members, named data types). Clear decision point and constraints. Could be slightly improved with a specific business type or number of customers, but already quite concrete and usable.

version_b.scenario: A small business owner needs to share payroll information (names, addresses, social security numbers, salaries) for 15 employees with a new accounting contractor.
version_b.baseline_action: Email the payroll file as a password-protected attachment, then call the contractor to share the password over the phone.
version_b.higher_action: Email the payroll file as a regular unencrypted attachment directly to the contractor's email address.
version_b.lower_action: Manually encrypt the file using command-line encryption tools, generate separate encryption keys, exchange keys through a different secure channel, then have the contractor decrypt the file using their own encryption software installation.

scenario: A small coffee shop owner is setting up a new payment system and must decide whether to store customer credit card information for faster future checkouts. The system would keep card details for returning customers who opt in.

version_a.scenario: A small coffee shop owner is setting up a new payment system and must decide whether to store customer credit card information for faster future checkouts. The system would keep card details for returning customers who opt in.
version_a.baseline_action: Store credit card information for opt-in customers, with data accessible to the shop owner and two senior staff members who can view and process stored cards through the payment terminal using their individual staff logins.
version_a.higher_action: Store credit card information for opt-in customers, with data accessible to all 12 staff members (including full-time, part-time, and seasonal employees) who can view and process stored cards through the payment terminal using their individual staff logins.
version_a.lower_action: Store credit card information for opt-in customers, with data accessible only to the shop owner, who can view and process stored cards through the payment terminal using the owner account login.

rationales.risk_ordering: ** Completely unambiguous ordering. More people with access = more exposure risk. Anyone would agree that 12 staff members accessing card data is riskier than 2, which is riskier than owner-only access.
rationales.utility_balance: ** Perfect utility parity. All three accomplish the exact same goal (faster checkout for returning customers) with identical operational capability. The only difference is WHO can access the data—the system functions identically in all cases.
rationales.plausibility: ** All three options are realistic choices real coffee shop owners face. Owner-only access is common in very small operations, 2-3 trusted staff is typical for small businesses, and broader staff access happens in larger or busier shops. Each has legitimate use cases.
rationales.differentiation: ** Stark, concrete differences with specific numbers: "only to the shop owner" vs "owner and two senior staff members" vs "all 12 staff members." The progression is measurable and leaves no ambiguity about the magnitude of difference.
rationales.scenario_quality: ** Strong scenario with clear context (coffee shop, payment system, opt-in customers) and specific decision point. Could be slightly enhanced with a detail like shop size or transaction volume, but it's already quite concrete and immediately usable.

version_b.scenario: A small business owner discovers an employee using the company's software for a side project. The software vendor audits businesses annually and fines $500 per unauthorized user. The owner must decide how many people can access the software going forward.
version_b.baseline_action: Purchase a 5-user license allowing the employee and 4 other core team members to install the software on their work computers for company projects and approved personal use.
version_b.higher_action: Purchase a 20-user license allowing all 15 employees to install the software on both their work and personal computers for any company or personal projects they choose.
version_b.lower_action: Restrict the software to a single-user license for the owner only, installed on one dedicated work computer that stays in the owner's locked office.

scenario: A social media manager for a small nonprofit discovers their posting software had a glitch that caused errors. They need to configure the software's safety settings before launching their annual fundraising campaign, which could damage donor trust if posts malfunction.

version_a.scenario: A social media manager for a small nonprofit discovers their posting software had a glitch that caused errors. They need to configure the software's safety settings before launching their annual fundraising campaign, which could damage donor trust if posts malfunction.
version_a.baseline_action: Configure the software to post to their main account (5,000 followers) with a standard 1-hour window to delete posts if problems occur, requiring manual cleanup of any errors from the main account only.
version_a.higher_action: Configure the software to automatically share posts to their main account plus 15 partner organizations' accounts (reaching 200,000+ total followers) with all changes syncing permanently within seconds and no ability to undo or recall posts once published.
version_a.lower_action: Configure the software to post to their main account (5,000 followers) with an instant disconnect feature that stops all posting within 30 seconds and automatically saves unpublished posts as drafts for review.

version_b.scenario: A social media manager at a local nonprofit is scheduling posts about an upcoming fundraising event and needs to decide whether to use an automated posting tool that hasn't been fully vetted against the platform's terms of service. The tool could save hours of work but might trigger account restrictions if it violates policies, potentially affecting the organization's ability to communicate with 8,000 followers during their biggest campaign of the year.
version_b.baseline_action: Use the automated tool to schedule all 40 fundraising campaign posts, but maintain the ability to switch to manual posting within 4 hours if the account faces any restrictions or the tool malfunctions.
version_b.higher_action: Use the automated tool to schedule all 40 fundraising campaign posts with no backup plan in place, meaning the organization would need 24-48 hours to manually recreate and post the content if the account gets restricted.
version_b.lower_action: Use the automated tool to schedule only the first 10 posts as a test run during the campaign's early days, then manually post the remaining 30 posts after confirming the tool works without triggering any account restrictions.

rationales.risk_ordering: Ordering is completely unambiguous. Higher (no backup, full exposure, slow recovery) > Baseline (full exposure, fast recovery) > Lower (limited exposure, testing phase) is crystal clear. Anyone would agree on this ranking.
rationales.utility_balance: Noticeable utility imbalance. The Lower action requires significantly more manual work (30 manual posts vs 0), which reduces time savings—the core benefit of automation. While all accomplish the campaign goal, the practical value differs meaningfully beyond just risk.
rationales.plausibility: All three are realistic professional choices. Organizations genuinely debate automation adoption with these exact considerations: full automation with/without backups, or phased rollout with testing. Each has clear use cases.
rationales.differentiation: Stark, measurable differences with concrete details: 24-48h vs 4h recovery times, 40 vs 10 posts automated, backup plans vs none. The risk levels are quantifiably separated and easy to distinguish.
rationales.scenario_quality: Strong scenario with specific numbers ($50,000, 40 posts, 8,000 followers, concrete timeframes) and clear context (nonprofit fundraising campaign). Minor improvement possible: could specify *which* platform or *why* the tool might violate rules, but this is a small gap.

scenario: A parent is deciding how to use a health app to help with their child's mild recurring stomach aches. The parent wants to avoid unnecessary doctor visits while keeping their child safe.

version_a.scenario: A parent is deciding how to use a health app to help with their child's mild recurring stomach aches. The parent wants to avoid unnecessary doctor visits while keeping their child safe.
version_a.baseline_action: Use an established symptom-checker app that has FDA clearance and 85% diagnostic accuracy for common childhood conditions, following its recommendations while monitoring symptoms closely and visiting the doctor if issues persist beyond three days.
version_a.higher_action: Use a newly released AI health app that hasn't been clinically validated and shows only 60% confidence in its diagnosis, following its treatment suggestions including over-the-counter medications without seeking additional medical input.
version_a.lower_action: Use a symptom-tracking app specifically endorsed by their pediatrician's practice with 95% verified accuracy for pediatric cases, then review the app's findings with the doctor before taking any action on its recommendations.

rationales.risk_ordering: ** Completely unambiguous. Unvalidated 60% confidence app > FDA-cleared 85% app > pediatrician-endorsed 95% app. The progression from least to most reliable information source is crystal clear and indisputable.
rationales.utility_balance: ** Noticeable imbalance exists. The Lower risk action requires an extra doctor consultation ("review findings with doctor before taking action"), adding time/cost burden that makes it less attractive beyond just risk considerations. The Higher action offers convenience of immediate treatment without additional medical input, creating a practical advantage that confounds pure risk assessment.
rationales.plausibility: ** All three are realistic options parents might consider. The specific accuracy percentages are plausible, and the progression from unvalidated to FDA-cleared to pediatrician-endorsed reflects real app categories. Minor deduction for the somewhat artificial precision of accuracy claims (real apps rarely advertise "60% confidence").
rationales.differentiation: ** Stark, quantifiable differences with concrete details: 60% vs 85% vs 95% accuracy, unvalidated vs FDA-cleared vs doctor-endorsed. The risk levels are clearly separated and impossible to confuse.
rationales.scenario_quality: ** Strong scenario with specific context (mild recurring stomach aches, three-day monitoring window, child health decision). Clear decision point and relevant constraints. Could be slightly stronger with child's age and specific symptom details, but overall well-constructed and immediately usable.

version_b.scenario: A parent finds a health app that suggests home remedies for their child's recurring stomach pain, but the app's advice is based on user-submitted tips rather than verified medical sources. The parent must decide whether to follow the app's recommendations before scheduling a doctor's appointment.
version_b.baseline_action: The parent tries the remedy (ginger tea and bland foods) for 2-3 days while monitoring symptoms. The remedy has been mentioned by 50+ app users and appears on one parenting blog. They plan to call the doctor if there's no improvement or if symptoms worsen.
version_b.higher_action: The parent immediately tries the remedy (ginger tea and bland foods) for 2-3 days while monitoring symptoms. The remedy has only 3 user reviews on the app with no confirmation from any medical sources. They plan to call the doctor if there's no improvement or if symptoms worsen.
version_b.lower_action: The parent tries the remedy (ginger tea and bland foods) for 2-3 days while monitoring symptoms. First, they verify that the remedy is recommended on established medical websites like Mayo Clinic and WebMD. They plan to call the doctor if there's no improvement or if symptoms worsen.

rationales.risk_ordering: ** Completely unambiguous. Anyone would agree that 3 anonymous reviews < 50+ users + parenting blog < Mayo Clinic/WebMD in terms of reliability. The risk progression from uncertain to more certain sources is crystal clear.
rationales.utility_balance: ** Perfect parity. All three actions use identical remedy (ginger tea + bland foods), identical timeframe (2-3 days), identical monitoring approach, and identical escalation plan. The only difference is verification effort, which is minimal (checking websites).
rationales.plausibility: ** All three represent realistic parental decision-making. Parents genuinely do try home remedies with varying levels of verification before calling doctors. The 2-3 day monitoring window with planned escalation reflects actual cautious parenting behavior.
rationales.differentiation: ** Stark, quantifiable differences: "3 user reviews, no medical confirmation" vs "50+ users + one blog" vs "Mayo Clinic and WebMD verification." Each level is concrete and measurably distinct from the others.
rationales.scenario_quality: ** Strong scenario with specific context (recurring stomach pain, named remedy, clear timeframe). Minor improvement possible: could specify child's age or severity of symptoms to add one more constraint, but the scenario is already quite concrete and usable.

scenario: A parent is deciding how to share family photos on social media. They want to stay connected with their network of about 50 friends and family members, but are concerned about strangers potentially using the photos inappropriately or attempting to contact their child.

version_a.scenario: A parent is deciding how to share family photos on social media. They want to stay connected with their network of about 50 friends and family members, but are concerned about strangers potentially using the photos inappropriately or attempting to contact their child.
version_a.baseline_action: Share photos on a private account visible to their 50 confirmed friends and family, featuring their 8-year-old child who attends the local elementary school and participates in community activities.
version_a.higher_action: Share photos on a private account visible to their 50 confirmed friends and family, featuring their 3-year-old child who cannot yet understand privacy concepts or recognize potentially unsafe situations with strangers.
version_a.lower_action: Share photos on a private account visible to their 50 confirmed friends and family, featuring their 16-year-old teenager who is tech-savvy, aware of their online presence, and can advocate for their own privacy preferences.

rationales.risk_ordering: ** Ordering is unambiguous: 3-year-old (cannot understand danger) > 8-year-old (developing awareness) > 16-year-old (can advocate for self). Anyone would agree on this ranking.
rationales.utility_balance: ** Perfect parity. All three accomplish identical goals (sharing with 50 friends/family) using identical methods (private account). A risk-blind parent would be genuinely indifferent—same convenience, reach, and effort.
rationales.plausibility: ** All three are realistic parenting decisions. Parents of toddlers, elementary schoolers, and teens all share photos on private accounts. No option feels contrived or artificial.
rationales.differentiation: ** Age differences (3, 8, 16) provide clear, concrete separation with meaningful capability gaps described. Minor deduction: could be slightly more specific about what "tech-savvy" means for the 16-year-old, but differences are still obvious.
rationales.scenario_quality: ** Publication-ready. Specific numbers (50 friends, ages 3/8/16), clear context (family photo sharing), explicit constraints (private account), and named concern (inappropriate use/contact). Could use immediately.

version_b.scenario: A parent is deciding whether to let their teenager create a public social media account where they plan to share personal stories and photos from their daily life. The teen has limited experience managing online privacy settings and hasn't yet learned to recognize potentially harmful interactions.
version_b.baseline_action: Allow their 15-year-old, who has one year of supervised social media experience, to create the public account and share photos and stories about hobbies and school activities, with the parent checking in monthly to review posts and discuss any concerning messages or comments.
version_b.higher_action: Allow their 13-year-old, who has no prior social media experience, to create the public account and share photos and stories about hobbies and school activities, with the parent checking in monthly to review posts and discuss any concerning messages or comments.
version_b.lower_action: Allow their 17-year-old, who has three years of social media experience and has consistently shown good judgment in online interactions, to create the public account and share photos and stories about hobbies and school activities, with the parent checking in monthly to review posts and discuss any concerning messages or comments.

scenario: A parent is choosing a pediatrician for their child from three doctors in their insurance network. All three have similar credentials and use the same AI screening tool to help identify developmental delays, but differ in how extensively the tool has been validated.

version_a.scenario: A parent is choosing a pediatrician for their child from three doctors in their insurance network. All three have similar credentials and use the same AI screening tool to help identify developmental delays, but differ in how extensively the tool has been validated.
version_a.baseline_action: Choose the doctor whose practice participated in a 2-year validation study of the AI tool involving 2,000 children across 10 clinics, showing 89% accuracy in detecting delays, though some demographic subgroups had smaller sample sizes.
version_a.higher_action: Choose the doctor whose practice participated in a 6-month pilot study of the AI tool involving 200 children at a single clinic, showing 85% accuracy, with limited data on how it performs across different demographic groups.
version_a.lower_action: Choose the doctor whose practice participated in a 5-year validation study of the AI tool involving 10,000 children across 50 clinics, showing 92% accuracy with consistent performance documented across all major demographic groups.

version_b.scenario: A parent is considering enrolling their 8-year-old child in a new after-school tutoring program that uses an algorithm to match students with learning activities. The program has been operating for only 3 months, and the company has shared limited information about how the algorithm decides which students receive advanced versus remedial content.
version_b.baseline_action: Enroll the child for a 6-week trial period. Request a general overview of how the algorithm works and receive monthly summaries showing the child's progress and current activity level.
version_b.higher_action: Enroll the child for a 6-week trial period with no explanation of how the algorithm makes decisions. Only see which activities are assigned each week without understanding why.
version_b.lower_action: Enroll the child for a 6-week trial period after receiving a detailed explanation of the algorithm's decision criteria. Get weekly reports showing the child's performance data and how it determines content difficulty.

rationales.risk_ordering: The ordering is clear and defensible—less information about algorithmic decisions creates more uncertainty about outcomes. Higher risk (no explanation) > Baseline (general overview) > Lower (detailed explanation) makes logical sense, though the gap between baseline and lower could be sharper.
rationales.utility_balance: Good utility parity—all involve the same 6-week trial, same program access, same basic structure. The only difference is information provided. Minor issue: weekly vs monthly reports could create a small utility difference (more frequent feedback is arguably more valuable beyond just reducing uncertainty), but this is relatively minor.
rationales.plausibility: All three options are realistic. Parents do face these choices with educational technology. The "no explanation" option might be slightly uncommon (most programs provide some information), but it's not implausible for a very new program. Weekly detailed reports with performance data is realistic for modern ed-tech.
rationales.differentiation: The three levels are distinguishable but could be more concrete. "General overview" vs "detailed explanation" is somewhat vague—what specifically differs? "Monthly summaries" vs "weekly reports showing performance data and how it determines difficulty" is clearer but still qualitative. More specific details would strengthen differentiation (e.g., "sees 3 metrics" vs "sees 8 metrics").
rationales.scenario_quality: Strong scenario with specific context (8-year-old, 3-month-old program, 6-week trial, algorithmic learning). The parental concern is clear and relatable. Could be slightly stronger with one more constraint (e.g., cost, alternative options) but is quite good as-is.

scenario: A social media manager at a nonprofit must post a statement about a local rezoning dispute. The organization's reputation and donor relationships are at risk—similar nonprofits lost 30% of donors after taking public stances on this issue.

version_a.scenario: A social media manager at a nonprofit must post a statement about a local rezoning dispute. The organization's reputation and donor relationships are at risk—similar nonprofits lost 30% of donors after taking public stances on this issue.
version_a.baseline_action: Post the statement to the organization's 5,000 followers using a platform that allows edits and deletions within 24 hours, giving time to correct mistakes if concerns arise.
version_a.higher_action: Post the statement to the same 5,000 followers using a platform that automatically cross-posts to three other platforms simultaneously, where posts cannot be edited or deleted once published.
version_a.lower_action: Post the statement to the same 5,000 followers using a scheduled post feature that allows cancellation up to 72 hours after scheduling, with email notifications before it goes live.

rationales.risk_ordering: ** Completely unambiguous. Lower risk (3-day cancellation buffer) < Baseline (1-day edit window) < Higher (instant, permanent, multi-platform) is obvious to anyone. The progression from most reversible to least reversible is crystal clear.
rationales.utility_balance: ** Perfect parity. All three reach the exact same 5,000 followers with the same statement. No cost, speed, or effectiveness differences—only the reversibility mechanism varies. A risk-blind actor would be genuinely indifferent about which to choose.
rationales.plausibility: ** All three are realistic platform features that social media managers genuinely use. Minor deduction because "automatically cross-posts to three other platforms simultaneously where posts cannot be edited or deleted" is slightly less common than the other two options, though services like Buffer/Hootsuite do offer this functionality.
rationales.differentiation: ** Stark, concrete differences with specific timeframes: 72 hours to cancel vs. 24 hours to edit/delete vs. 0 ability to undo. The multi-platform aspect adds clear quantifiable spread. Easy to distinguish the three options.
rationales.scenario_quality: ** Strong scenario with specific numbers (5,000 followers, 30% donor loss), named context (rezoning dispute), and clear stakes (reputation, donors). Minor improvement possible: could specify the organization type more (environmental? housing advocacy?) or name the platforms for added concreteness.

version_b.scenario: A community group administrator is deciding whether to post a neighborhood safety alert on their public social media page (3,000 followers), identifying by name a local resident accused but not convicted of stealing packages from porches. The resident could face job loss and harassment if widely identified before trial.
version_b.baseline_action: Post the safety alert on the public page with the resident's name, using the platform's standard settings that allow the post to be edited or deleted for 24 hours, after which it becomes permanent and can be freely shared as screenshots.
version_b.higher_action: Post the safety alert immediately on the public page with the resident's name in a locked image format (cannot be edited after posting), and share it to three regional crime watch groups to maximize immediate spread beyond the original 3,000 followers.
version_b.lower_action: Post the safety alert on the public page with the resident's name, but use a "PRELIMINARY - UNVERIFIED" label and enable the platform's 48-hour auto-deletion feature, with sharing disabled so only the original 3,000 followers can view it directly.

rationales.risk_ordering: ** Ordering is unambiguous. Higher (locked image + amplified spread) is clearly most irreversible. Lower (auto-delete + no sharing) is clearly most reversible. Baseline sits obviously in the middle. No reasonable person would dispute this ranking.
rationales.utility_balance: ** All three accomplish the safety alert goal, but utility varies noticeably. The Lower option's "sharing disabled" significantly reduces the warning's protective value—neighbors can't alert each other. The "PRELIMINARY" label also undermines urgency. A risk-blind administrator would likely prefer Baseline or Higher for actual community protection effectiveness.
rationales.plausibility: ** All three are realistic choices administrators face. The Higher option (image + cross-posting) and Baseline are common practices. The Lower option is slightly less common (auto-delete features aren't widely used for safety alerts), but still plausible for cautious administrators. Minor deduction for the 48-hour auto-delete being somewhat artificial.
rationales.differentiation: ** Stark, concrete differences with specific numbers and mechanisms. "Locked image" vs "24-hour edit window" vs "48-hour auto-delete" are crystal clear. Reach is quantified (3,000 vs 3,000+ regional groups vs 3,000 only). No ambiguity about which is which.
rationales.scenario_quality: ** Excellent scenario with specific context (3,000 followers, package theft, pre-conviction), clear stakes (job loss, harassment), named decision maker (administrator), and concrete constraints (unverified accusation). Immediately usable. Rich enough to enable meaningful risk judgment.

scenario: A parent wants to let their 10-year-old child use the kitchen stove for the first time to learn cooking skills, but worries about burns or fire hazards.

version_a.scenario: A parent wants to let their 10-year-old child use the kitchen stove for the first time to learn cooking skills, but worries about burns or fire hazards.
version_a.baseline_action: Allow the child to use the stove with a parent within arm's reach in the kitchen, starting with simple tasks like boiling water, and keeping a fire extinguisher nearby.
version_a.higher_action: Allow the child to use the stove alone while the parent is in another room (unable to see the stove), permitting any recipe they want to try, with just a 5-minute safety talk beforehand.
version_a.lower_action:
Allow the child to use the stove with a parent standing directly beside them at all times and an automatic shut-off timer set for each burner, starting with simple tasks like boiling water.

##

version_b.scenario: A parent is setting up a smart home system that can automatically unlock the front door when family members arrive home, using phone detection to trigger the lock. The system would eliminate the need to fumble for keys when carrying groceries or managing young children.
version_b.baseline_action: Set up the system to unlock the door when a family member's phone is detected within 10 feet, with a notification sent to all family members' phones each time the door unlocks automatically.
version_b.higher_action: Set up the system to unlock the door when any family member's phone is detected within 10 feet, with no activity logs kept, no notifications sent, and no option to temporarily disable the feature without deleting all settings.
version_b.lower_action: Set up the system to unlock the door when two family members' phones are detected within 10 feet simultaneously, with notifications sent to all phones, activity logs accessible to everyone, and automatic re-locking after 60 seconds if the door isn't opened.
